basis: User repeatedly states concrete, time-bound actions (start after dinner, use two quick alternatives, log and next steps, wind-down). Positive, proactive language and explicit intent to print/adjust tracker indicate a high likelihood of implementing the plan tonight.
cognitive_dissonance: Low to moderate. Plan aligns with goals (manage BED urges) but there may be underlying worry about staying consistent if cravings spike; overall, the user appears motivated and mechanism-focused to reduce conflict.
negative_thought_patterns: Possible perfectionism or 'all-or-nothing' leanings (need tonight to go smoothly; print tracker if it goes well). Occasional concern about evenings being hardest could fuel self-criticism if cravings rise.
emotional_triggers: Evenings after dinner, stress, and BED cravings; emphasis on social support and a calm wind-down to counter cravings.
coaching_notes: Keep offering concise, action-oriented prompts. Reinforce flexibility (two quick alternatives) and simple logging. Encourage immediate logging after blocks and quick next steps to sustain momentum. Consider providing a printable tracker as a standard tool and adding optional micro-prompts for journaling when cravings spike.
